tutorial.text: Unlike wallets in real life, crypto wallets can't hold actual money. Instead, crypto wallets provide keys that prove ownership to cryptocurrency or NFTs that exist on a blockchain.
Crypto wallets store two types of keys, private and public keys. These keys come in pairs; every private key can generate a public key.
Private keys are secret, randomly generated numbers that act similar to a password. They grant access to the cryptocurrency or NFTs that belongs to that key.
If your private keys gets lost or stolen, anything those private keys granted access to are no longer yours. NEVER share your private keys.
To help keep your private keys safe, wallets generate a seed phrase. A seed phrase is a backup recovery phrase that gives access to a wallet. NEVER share your seed phrase.
Public keys are used by wallets to generate public addresses. Sharing your public address allows you to receive cryptocurrency.

tutorial.text: There are two main groups of crypto wallets, "hot" wallets and "cold" wallets. They have their own advantages and disadvantages.
Desktop and mobile wallets are examples of "hot" wallets because they are connected to the internet. However, this makes them vulnerable to online attacks.
If your computer or mobile device is hacked, your crypto may be compromised as a result. It is not suggested to hold large amounts of crypto long term on online wallets.
Web wallets are online services that will manage your keys on your behalf. This is known as a custodial wallet, which is convenient, but also adds more risk of your crypto vanishing.
A hardware wallet is an example of a "cold" wallet. They are safer because they store privates keys offline, completely inaccessible to malicious online threats.
An ideal strategy would be to use hardware wallets for long term storage, while using a non-custodial online wallet for short term transations.
